questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of fatigue and difficulty swallowing. During this period, she has also had dry skin, thinning hair, and rounding of her face. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus and rheumatoid arthritis.  Her father had a thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer. The patient had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 3 years ago. She drinks 2–3 glasses of wine daily. Her current medications include insulin, omeprazole, and daily ibuprofen. She appears well. Her temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 62/min, and blood pressure is 102/76 mm Hg. Examination of the neck shows a painless, diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures on thyroid biopsy
Large irregular nuclei, nuclear grooves, and Psammoma bodies on thyroid biopsy
Increased uptake in a discrete 1-cm area on a radioactive iodine scan
Uniform and diffusely increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan
Positive TSH receptor antibodies and thyroglobulin antibodies in serum
Positive thyroid peroxidase antibodies and thyroglobulin antibodies in serum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures would be seen on a biopsy of anaplastic thyroid cancer, which typically presents with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. Such a neck mass may cause pain or compressive symptoms, such as hoarseness or dysphagia, the latter of which the patient has. However, anaplastic thyroid cancer is not typically associated with symptoms of hypo- or hyperthyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Large, irregular nuclei, nuclear grooves, and Psammoma bodies would be seen on a biopsy of papillary thyroid cancer, which typically presents as a discrete thyroid nodule. A history of rapid enlargement and evidence of surrounding tissue involvement, such as nodule fixation, hoarseness, or vocal cord paralysis, would increase suspicion of malignancy. Although this patient does have dysphagia and a positive family history, her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged without a discrete nodule. Also, papillary thyroid cancer is not typically associated with clinical hypo- or hyperthyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

A discrete area of radioactive iodine uptake (hot nodule) may be seen in toxic adenomas, which primarily present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism. However, this patient presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism, which is inconsistent with the diagnosis of toxic adenoma and its associated findings on a radioactive iodine scan.

D) INCORRECT:

A uniform and diffusely increased radioiodine uptake would be suggestive of Graves disease, which can manifest with goiter but it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. Patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis have a highly variable tracer uptake on a radioactive iodine scan with diffusely decreased radioiodine uptake reported in approx. 30% of patients.

E) INCORRECT:

An elevation of both TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb) and thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAb) is a typical finding in patients with Graves disease, which can manifest with a goiter but would cause symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, anxiety, tremor, sweating, palpitations), not hypothyroidism. TRAb is less commonly seen in patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis (only approx. 10–15% of cases).

F) CORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and thyroglobulin (Tg) are typically only present in the thyroid gland and thus sequestered from the systemic immune system. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, genetic and environmental factors are thought to cause immune sensitization to self-antigens such as TPO and Tg, which results in chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland. As such, thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPOAb) and thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAb) can be detected in the majority of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis and can be used to assess disease activity (see “Overview of thyroid antibodies” table).

Radioactive iodine scan is not part of the regular workup of Hashimoto thyroiditis; the findings are highly variable but iodine uptake may be decreased in transient thyrotoxicosis. A thyroid biopsy would show diffuse lymphocytic infiltration with Hurthle cells and fibrotic tissue. Patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis also have a high risk of developing a thyroid lymphoma; a thyroid lymphoma should be suspected if a patient with Hashimoto thyroiditis has a rapidly growing goiter.
questions.hint: This patient has a diffusely enlarged thyroid (goiter), symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, hair thinning, rounding of the face), and a history of autoimmune conditions, which makes Hashimoto thyroiditis the most likely diagnosis. A large goiter can cause dysphagia due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the hospital because of poor weight gain since birth. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via normal vaginal delivery. He weighed 3005 g (6 lb, 10 oz) at birth and currently weighs 2835 g (6 lb, 4 oz). He has been latching on and breastfeeding well since birth. His mother has a history of Graves disease and underwent near-total thyroidectomy in the second trimester of her pregnancy after her symptoms could not be controlled with antithyroid drugs. She is currently receiving L-thyroxine therapy. The patient's temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 176/min, and respirations are 42/min. He appears irritable. Examination shows a diaphoretic infant with a paucity of subcutaneous fat. There is swelling of the neck at the midline. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Activating mutation of the TSH receptor gene
Transplacental passage of thyroid peroxidase antibodies
Transplacental passage of TSH receptor antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAbs) are found in approx. 50–70% of patients with Graves disease and > 80% of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although this patient's mother has a history of Graves disease and the antibodies can pass the placenta, TgAbs are not thought to be involved in the pathogenesis of hyperthyroidism in Graves disease. Rather, they are believed to be a response to rapid cell destruction/disordered growth and subsequent release of circulating free thyroglobulin into the bloodstream. They are therefore not likely to be the cause of this infant's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

An activating mutation (or gain-of-function mutation) of the TSH receptor gene is the underlying pathophysiology of toxic adenoma. Since toxic adenomas produce large amounts of thyroid hormones, independent of normal hypothalamic-pituitary feedback regulation, they also cause hyperthyroidism. However, the condition is most common in adults between 30–50 years of age and would be unlikely in a neonate.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPOAbs) are present in ∼ 70% of patients with Graves disease and > 90% of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although this patient's mother has a history of Graves disease and the antibodies can pass the placenta, TPOAbs are not known to be involved in the pathogenesis of hyperthyroidism in Graves disease, but rather result from the autoimmune nature of the condition. They are therefore not likely to be the cause of this infant's symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Up to 5% of infants born to mothers with Graves disease develop thyrotoxicosis due to the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH-receptor antibodies (TRAbs). TRAbs are present in ∼ 90% of patients with Graves disease and cause increased growth and function of the thyroid gland and the subsequent development of hyperthyroidism and goiter. Neonatal thyrotoxicosis is transient and usually resolves within 12 weeks, when maternal TRAbs disappear from the infant's circulation. Although the condition is transient, symptomatic neonatal thyrotoxicosis should be treated as soon as it is diagnosed to prevent complications such as cardiac failure, intellectual disability, and craniosynostosis. Therapy consists of methimazole to achieve a euthyroid state and a beta blocker (e.g., propranolol) to rapidly control the thyrotoxic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Although L-thyroxine has a long half-life (6–7 days), L-thyroxine only minimally crosses the placenta and is considered a category A drug during pregnancy, i.e., controlled human studies showed no risk for the fetus. It would therefore be an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: This neonate has features highly suggestive of neonatal thyrotoxicosis: irritability, tachycardia, goiter, diaphoresis, and poor weight gain since birth despite an adequate appetite. The mother's history of Graves disease provides a clue for the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss despite eating more than usual. Her pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 140/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, moist skin, and a diffuse, non-tender swelling over the anterior neck. Ophthalmologic examination shows swelling of the eyelids and proptosis bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nongranulomatous inflammation of the thyroid occurs in Hashimoto thyroiditis and subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis. Patients with either condition may initially present with an enlarged, painless thyroid gland and signs of hyperthyroidism secondary to transient thyroxine release from destroyed thyrocytes. However, these conditions are not associated with eyelid swelling or exophthalmos.

B) CORRECT:

Graves disease is caused by thyrotropin-receptor autoantibodies (TRAbs) that activate the TSH receptor. TRAbs induce hyperthyroidism by stimulating follicular epithelial cells to produce abnormally high amounts of triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4). As seen in this patient, the metabolically active free T3 increases the basal metabolic rate and lipolysis, which manifests as weight loss, high blood pressure, and increased body temperature. TSH receptor antibodies also bind to orbital TSH receptors and stimulate adipocyte proliferation and orbital fibroblast secretion of glycosaminoglycans. Increased adipocyte count, osmotic muscle swelling, and muscle inflammation cause expansion of retro-orbital tissue, which manifests as exophthalmos and decreased ocular motility.

Graves disease is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-B8 immunophenotypes. Histological examination of the goiter in Graves disease would reveal tall, follicular epithelial cells with scalloped colloid spaces.
Image Description:

Orbital area of a 32-year-old patient with Graves disease and symptoms of binocular diplopia

The globe protrudes out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos); the upper eyelids are retracted, resulting in the superior sclera becoming visible (Dalrymple sign). There is, furthermore, conjunctival injection and edema of the eyelids. The combination of findings indicates Graves orbitopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

De Quervain thyroiditis is associated with granuloma formation and multinucleated giant cells. This condition may initially manifest with symptoms of hyperthyroidism caused by transient thyroxine release from destroyed thyrocytes. However, de Quervain thyroiditis is not associated with eyelid swelling or exophthalmos. Moreover, patients with this condition classically present with tender goiter and jaw pain.
Image Description:

Ultrasound thyroid (longitudinal plane)

A geographic hypoechoic area (blue overlay) is seen within the thyroid gland.

This appearance can be seen with subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis). The lesions may be unilateral or bilateral, and gland size may be small, normal, or enlarged. The hypoechoic areas may show reduced or absent blood flow on color Doppler.

T: normal thyroid parenchyma

D) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid cancer is caused by hyperplasia of parafollicular cells. Patients with this condition may present with painless swelling of the thyroid. However, medullary thyroid cancer does not manifest with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, and it is not associated with eye changes.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 300x magnification)

Green overlay: tumor cell nests
Black arrows: fibrous bands with prominent vascularity

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase antibodies prevent the production of thyroid hormone in Hashimoto thyroiditis. Patients with this condition may initially present with an enlarged, painless thyroid gland and hyperthyroidism secondary to transient thyroxine release from destroyed thyrocytes (hashitoxicosis). However, Hashimoto's thyroiditis is not associated with eyelid swelling or exophthalmos.
Image Description:

Ultrasound thyroid (right lobe; longitudinal plane; a: B-mode; b: with power Doppler)

Widely distributed hypoechoic micronodules (examples indicated by arrows) have resulted in a heterogenous echotexture. Power Doppler shows diffusely increased vascularity (red).

Ultrasound features in Hashimoto thyroiditis can vary with the phase and severity of the disease. The thyroid gland may appear enlarged and hypervascular in early-stage disease and small and hypovascular in later stages of disease. Micronodularity and a pseudonodular appearance (also known as “giraffe pattern”) are patterns that result from lymphocytic infiltration and strongly suggest diffuse Hashimoto thyroiditis. Hashimoto thyroiditis may also appear as larger focal nodules.

F) INCORRECT:

Constitutively active thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors can lead to the development of a toxic multinodular goiter. Although patients with the condition present with classic symptoms of hyperthyroidism, they do not have eyelid swelling or exophthalmos. Moreover, the condition manifests with nodular neck swelling, as opposed to the diffuse neck swelling in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with clinical findings of hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease, including unintentional weight loss, warm, moist skin, tachycardia, hypertension, painless goiter, and ophthalmopathy.
